Article Title: BSF foils another infiltration attempt in Jammu, one Pakistan intruder shot dead
Article Text: NEW DELHI: The Border security Force on Wednesday foiled an infiltration bid and neutralised one Pakistani intruder along the international border in the Samba border area, PTI reported.According to officials, The infiltrator was spotted moving into Indian territory near the Khora post.They said the intruder paid no heed to the warnings from BSF personnel and was subsequently fired upon.Senior BSF and police officials have reached the area of incident and efforts are on to retrieve the body.
Article Summary: The infiltrator was spotted moving into Indian territory near the Khora post. The intruder paid no heed to the warnings from BSF personnel and was subsequently fired upon. Senior BSF and police officials have reached the area of incident and efforts are on to retrieve the body.

Article Title: 'Exercise caution': India's advisory for its citizens in Lebanon amid tense situation
Article Text: NEW DELHI: The Indian embassy in Beirut issued an advisory on Thursday cautioning Indian citizens residing in Lebanon amid the recent escalation in the Middle East following the rising tensions between Israel and the Lebanon-based Hezbollah group.Advising against non-essential travel to Lebanon, the embassy said, "In view of the recent escalations in the region, Indian nationals are advised to avoid all non-essential travel to Lebanon.""All Indian nationals in Lebanon are advised to exercise caution, restrict their movements, and remain in contact with the Embassy of India in Beirut through their email: cons.beirut@mea.gov.in or the emergency phone number +96176860128," it added.This comes after Hezbollah senior commander Fuad Shukr was killed in an Israeli strike on the outskirts of the Lebanese capital in a Hezbollah stronghold.The strike, which was followed by another, hours later, which killed Hamas political leader Ismail Haniyeh in Tehran, triggered fears the war in Gaza could escalate into a region-wide conflict.
Article Summary: The Indian embassy in Beirut issued an advisory on Thursday cautioning Indian citizens residing in Lebanon. Advising against non-essential travel to Lebanon, the embassy said. This comes after Hezbollah senior commander Fuad Shukr was killed in an Israeli strike on the outskirts of the Lebanese capital in a Hezbollah stronghold.

Article Title: Further delay in deliveries of Tejas Mark-1A fighters to IAF
Article Text: NEW DELHI: Grappling with just 30 fighter squadrons when it is authorised 42 to face the threat from China and Pakistan, the IAF will to wait further for the deliveries of the indigenous Tejas Mark-1A jets to begin.The first of the 83 “improved” Tejas jets was to be delivered to IAF by March 31 this year, but will only be ready by September now, sources said on Wednesday.“Hindustan Aeronautics ( HAL ) at best will be able to deliver only half of the 16 jets it was supposed to deliver in the 2024-25 as per the contract,” a source said.TOI had earlier reported that there had been a major delay in the delivery timeframe of the 83 Tejas Mark-1A jets contracted from HAL under the Rs 46,898 crore contract in Feb 2021. Under it, all the 83 fighters are to be delivered by Feb 2028.While there has been a delay in delivery of F-404 engines by US firm General Electric to power the Tejas, sources said there were certain developmental issues by the HAL as well.This comes at a time when another Rs 67,000 crore contract for 97 more Tejas Mark-1A fighters is also being finalized. The Rajnath Singh-led Defence Acquisitions Council in Nov last year had given the preliminary nod or acceptance of necessity (AoN) for the acquisition of these 97 jets.Under the first-ever Rs 8,802 crore contract for 40 Tejas Mark-1 jets, HAL was supposed to finish the delivery by Dec 2016. But it has delivered only 35 of the 40 jets so far, with five trainers yet to be delivered.HAL will need to majorly crank up its annual production rate to deliver all the 180 Tejas Mark-1A jets, which are powered by GE-F404 engines, in time.The cabinet committee on security in August 2022 had also cleared the over Rs 9,000 crore development of the Tejas Mark-2 fighters, with the more powerful GE-F414 engines. IAF plans to induct six squadrons (108 jets) of Tejas Mark-2, which will have a longer combat range and greater weapon-carrying capacity than the Mark-1A variant.
Article Summary: The first of the 83 “improved” Tejas jets was to be delivered to IAF by March 31 this year, but will only be ready by September now. This comes at a time when another Rs 67,000 crore contract for 97 more Tejas Mark-1A fighters is also being finalized.

Article Title: Kerala landslide: Midnight run uphill into forest helps beat death
Article Text: KOCHI: As rains pounded the tiled roof of their small house located on the banks of Mundakkai river at Punchirivattom, just a kilometre from the landslide spot, Muhammed Basil, a 25-year-old software engineer, and his parents spent a nervous, sleepless night.Barely 10 minutes before the massive landslide on the hilltop in Mundakkai swept away hundreds of people and their houses early Tuesday, the family showed the presence of mind to quickly escape to the jungles and move up the hills.The decision saved the lives of Basil, his mother Suhara, 53 and his father Abdul Hameed, 57."My house was situated on the upstream end of the river. The heavy rainfall in the region made it difficult for us to sleep. Around 12.30 am, we saw the river waters gradually rising and seeping into our home. We quickly decided to seek refuge at my uncle's house, which was just a hundred metres away from ours. However, within minutes of reaching there, we heard the deafening sound of gushing water, and that house also began to shake," said Basil."The doors of my uncle's house were stuck as the entire house trembled, but we managed to crash it. Without wasting a breath, I took my mother and father outside, and we mustered all our strength to run up the hill and into the forest . Within seconds, the sudden gush of water, carrying huge boulders and trees, swept away our home and also our new two-storied house, which was in the finishing stage," Basil recounted the harrowing experience of that fateful night.After spending hours in the forest and traversing many routes, he and his parents took shelter at a nearby Tree Valley resort around 3am.Basil, who works in Kochi, had returned home weeks ago to oversee the completion of his new house, and was working from home. "Due to the modest size of our dwelling, we were constantly at a risk of being inundated by floodwaters. Building a new, secure home has always been my dream. Now, the landslide has swept away everything, leaving only debris in its wake," he lamented. Nearly 30 of his relatives and neighbours perished in the tragedy. "We don't know how to move forward and rebuild our lives," he said tearfully.Basil's father was a taxi driver and his mother was a daily wage worker. The family is now staying in a relief camp in Meppadi.
Article Summary: Muhammed Basil, his mother Suhara, 53 and his father Abdul Hameed, 57, lost their homes in Mundakkai landslide. The 25-year-old software engineer had returned home weeks ago to oversee the completion of his new house. Nearly 30 of his relatives and neighbours perished in the tragedy.

Article Title: Kind strangers offer final resting sites for departed
Article Text: WAYANAD : What nature's fury denied Mundakkai and Chooralmala 's dead, the kindness of strangers provided on Wednesday as mourning families desperately searched for resting places for their loved ones beyond the landslide-ravaged zone.Meppadi , around 15km away, was among the places where residents hurriedly made funeral arrangements for many of the victims.The burial grounds of Chooralmala Town Juma Masjid and Mundakkai Masjid were destroyed in the landslide that bore down on these two pockets of Wayanad early Tuesday. Cremation grounds at both places weren't spared either.Meppadi saw 30 burials in two days. Around 200 gravediggers from various districts dug up 50 graves in anticipation of more landslide victims being taken there.A Ashraf, vice president of Meppadi Juma Masjid Committee, said he and his colleagues held a meeting on hearing about the devastation in Mundakkai and Chooralmala and decided to help out their neighbours in every way possible, including burying the dead."We used to have just a couple of burials every month. But this is a monumental tragedy and we have had people volunteering from across the state to help dig graves. We are also receiving food items for distribution among the victims' families," he said.Sulaiman T was among those volunteering to help conduct mass funerals. Noushad K arrived in Meppadi from nearby Tharuvana to assist members of the mosque committee in digging graves.At least 23 cremations in accordance with Hindu rites were done at the grounds attached to the Meppadi Mariyappan temple since Tuesday. A few Christian funerals were also conducted by CSI Holy Emanual Church at Meppadi.
Article Summary: Meppadi saw 30 burials in two days. Around 200 gravediggers from various districts dug up 50 graves in anticipation of more landslide victims being taken there. At least 23 cremations in accordance with Hindu rites were done at the grounds attached to the Meppadi Mariyappan temple since Tuesday.

Article Title: Supreme Court pulls up Kerala government for withholding files from green panel
Article Text: NEW DELHI: Taking exception to Kerala government 's reluctance in sharing information with the Central Empowered Committee , which is statutory body on environmental issues, Supreme Court has directed the state's land revenue commissioner to appear before it along with the additional secretary of the department to respond to why contempt proceedings should not be initiated against them for "withholding" files sought by the panel."The CEC, originally constituted under the order of this court, has now received statutory recognition vide notification dated September 5, 2023. The said statutory status was also granted in pursuance to the directions issued by this court. The CEC is, therefore, discharging its duties in order to assist the court in hearing matters assigned to the bench hearing TN Godavarman Thirumulpad matter. Every authority is, therefore, bound to assist the CEC when the CEC conducts an enquiry. An attempt to withhold an important file, in our view, undermines the authority of this court. It prevents the CEC in discharging its duties of assisting the court," a bench headed by Justice B R Gavai said."We, therefore, issue notice to A Kowsigan, IAS, commissioner land revenue, and T R Jayapal, additional secretary, government of Kerala, and direct them to remain present in this court on August 21, 2024, and show cause as to why an action for committing contempt of the court may not be initiated against them by this court," the bench said.
Article Summary: Kerala government's reluctance in sharing information with the Central Empowered Committee. Supreme Court has directed the state's land revenue commissioner to appear before it along with the additional secretary of the department to respond to why contempt proceedings should not be initiated against them.

Article Title: Moving out in the nick of time saves residents of village in Kozhikode
Article Text: KOCHI: Nearly a dozen landslides occurred in Vilangad village in Kozhikode on the same night as the catastrophe in Wayanad . However, residents there were able to avert a tragedy as families living in as many as 18 houses which got washed away were relocated in time on the night before."Seeing the rain intensify, we asked people to move to safer places.If they had not moved, none of them would have been alive now. We had made calls on the phone to coordinate this," Vilangad panchayat member Selma Raju said.Mathew, a retired schoolteacher, went missing and despite efforts to find him on Wednesday he couldn't be traced. "He and a few others had gone to the location to see if there were people in distress following the primary landslides. However, a subsequent landslide took place suddenly, and he ran into a shop while the others went in the opposite direction. He couldn't get out of the shop and the others went to get a rope to get him across. But another major landslide happened in which the shop got washed away," said Selma, adding that his wife was safe and his children who are in Canada would return on Thursday.Father Abraham Kavylpurayidathil, a native of Vilangad, said that the devastation was widespread and if they had not taken precaution, several people would have died. "Huge boulders came tumbling down in the landslides. There was a small market there with a chapel, a couple shops and a village library and all of that has been washed away," Kavylpurayidathil said.
Article Summary: Nearly a dozen landslides occurred in Vilangad village in Kozhikode on the same night as the catastrophe in Wayanad. Residents there were able to avert a tragedy as families living in as many as 18 houses which got washed away were relocated in time.
